basics.name: Mohamed Hemdan
basics.label: Ph.D. Student
basics.summary: Ph.D. student at University of Minnesota, specializing in computer science, with research focus on spatial data management and federated learning.

work.name: Microsoft, Cairo, Egypt
work.summary: Analyzed user interactions and determined important factors for user engagement with notifications and news.
highlights: Determined high-priority features for improved user experience

work.name: European Council for Nuclear Research (CERN), Geneva, Switzerland
work.summary: Worked on federated learning for high-energy physics simulations and GAN model training for calorimeter simulations.
highlights: Developed a distributed GAN training model
Adapted models to federated learning for large-scale data

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Excellence in Undergraduate Research Award
awards.summary: Awarded for outstanding research in computer engineering during undergraduate studies.

awards.title: Dr. Sherif El-Kassas Award
awards.summary: Recognition for academic excellence in computer science.

certificates.name: Micro Masters in Statistics and Data Science

publications.name: Federated Learning Strategies of Generative Adversarial Networks for High Energy Physics Calorimeter Simulation
publications.summary: Paper on federated learning strategies using GANs for calorimeter simulations in high-energy physics.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
